label: Request for book donations by the committee of the South Carolina Bar Association, 1828
description: An 1828 broadside referencing a committee appointed by the South Carolina Bar Association to collect books for a library.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: An 1828 broadside referencing a committee appointed by the South Carolina Bar Association to collect books for a library.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information and reuse requirements contact Special Collections at Addlestone Library, College of Charleston, Charleston, SC, 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
1828
AS a committee of the South Carolina Bar Association appointed to collect Books by
donation or otherwise, permit us to ask of you such books, connected with the profession,
in its enlarged and liberal character, as you may be able to spare from your private library
Not only Law Books, properly so called, but any treatises on Moral Philosophy, on the
law of Nature and Nations, on Political Philosophy or Economy, or Constitutional law.
Any old and rare books, especially of the Ancient Law, will be acceptable; and as the object
is to make the Library a very complete one, in the course of years, we should esteem it a
favour to receive any works that may be spared of the following descriptions—Grammars
and Dictionaries in Greek, Latin, English, French, Spanish, and indeed in any language—
Works on Geography, Phlology, Belles Lettres, Logic, History, Biography, Antiquities,
and any of the Classics. Pmaplets, odd volumes, and any broken number of the Acts of
Assembly will be likewise acceptable. Donations may be sent to the Library [the former
Mesne Conveyance Office in the Court House,] or to the residence or office of any of the
committee.

Respectfully,
THOS. S. GRIMKE ] Committee
JOS. CLARKE, ]
H.N. CRUGER, ]

T.S. GRIMKE—Residence, 38 South Bay,-Office, 72 Broad Street, next to Dr. Ramsay’s.
JOS. CLARKE—Residence, 56 Tradd Street,- Office, 49 Bread Street.
H.N. CRUGER—Residence, 3 St. Philip’s Street,-Office, St. Michael’s Alley.
